issue.title: Better handle when configuration file is not present during bootstrapping
RFC: Introduce an interface for `Session` (v3 only)
issue.body:
I'd like to gauge the feasibility and willingness to introduce an interface for the `Session` class. There are 2 primary reasons I'd like this functionality:

1. Implementing the decorator pattern. There's functionality I'd like to provide on top of Amp's `Session`. An example of this is a "temporary" storage within the session that gets cleared out after use. I could provide my own interface for this functionality, but then I have to ensure this new API gets used everywhere and nobody uses Amp's Session directly. It would be better if I could decorate Amp's `Session` to provide this functionality and control what implementation gets injected as a dependency.
2. Testing. There are situations where it may be preferable to provide a stub or mock in Controller unit tests. This isn't currently possible.

Thanks for the Amp libraries and considering my idea!

comment.body:
Ok, sorry it took so long to respond to this. I didn't mean to leave this in a broken state.

There are 3 uses cases I have that I believe would benefit from the `Session` being an interface.

1. Define expiry conditions on session values

I would like to have some values stored in the session on a purely temporary basis. The first time some condition is met, in my case when the value is first read, I want them to be removed from the session. I'm imagining a decorated `Session` implementation that would keep track of a keys effective lifetime. In my mind it makes more sense to define this when writing the value, akin to defining a TTL for a cached value at write time, rather then everywhere it might be read.

It might be possible to do this in the `SessionStorage` interface but from what I understand that writes an entire collection of session data and I need to define these conditions on values _within_ that collection.

2. Logging Session information in development/debugging

It might be useful when debugging tricky situations to turn on heavy or verbose logging. Providing a decorated `Session` implementation that logs every read and write could provide useful information.

3. Providing a simpler implementation for tests

This one is less of a concern than the others but unit tests on a `RequestHandler` might benefit from less setup required to get a working Session together. I have done some of these type of unit tests and the existing setup allows for this pretty easily, but it would remove a little bit of boiler plate and make for slightly more understandable tests.

comment.body: Based on the type hint defined I wouldn't expect psalm to see the `$key` as null. However, static analysis complained about this. After having looked at the function that generates this key it seems like this will always be a `non-empty-string` in practice.

pull_request.title: Use proper header parsing function from ampphp/http
pull_request.body: The recent release of amphp/http v2 changed one of the function names. This patch updates the use of that function to the new name. I also added strict type declarations and added an `\assert()` call into the `SessionMiddleware` to get static analysis and code linting to pass checks.

issue.title: Include number of times a fixture was matched in error output
issue.body: Will need to consider how to provide this information to the `RequestNotMocked` exception.

issue.title: Improve output when a request does not match because of a custom matcher
issue.body: The error message displayed when a mocked interceptor does not match a given Request because of custom Matchers passed when setting up the mock does not display enough information. We should consider how to display pertinent information, keeping in mind that a subject under test might send multiple requests that might partially match other requests. In this scenario we shouldn't be overly noisy.
